IRM 1.22.8, Mailing and Shipping Equipment, dated August 15, 2018 is
AUDIENCE
IRS Employees
Table of Contents
Shipping Equipment
) Purpose: This section of the IRM describes the importance of mailing and shipping equipment. (
) Audience: The information in this section is for all IRS employees who Mail and Transportation Management decisions. (
) Policy Owner: The responsibility of administering the IRS mail and tion management program falls under the direction of the Commissioner, and Investment (W&I). (
) Program Owner: Distribution Requirements Branch is the program office sponsible for overseeing and providing guidance for the Mail and Transportation Management. (
) Primary Stakeholders: a. IRS Business Units b. Distribution Requirements Branch c. Postal and Transportation Policy d. All employees who use mailing and shipping services (
) Program goals: To provide information on the use of postage machines small parcel technology. (

) Every IRS office, whether operated by a staffed mailroom or self-serviced individual IRS employees, needs equipment for mailing and shipping. This section contains information about postage meters, Small Package Carrier (SPC) shipping systems and SPC web based shipping. Employees are reminded that it is forbidden to use Government property for conducting personal business or for other unauthorized personal purposes. property includes: • Office Supplies • Telephone and other telecommunications equipment and services • Government mail carried by agency personnel, contractors, the U.S. Postal Service and all other carriers • Government Mail Services • Automated data processing capabilities • Printing and reproduction facilities • Government records and Government vehicles, per

) Wage and Investment (W&I)/Media and Publications (M&P)/Distribution quirements Branch (DRB) provides guidance and support to the affected stakeholders, including expense veriﬁcation, adjustments and (

) Postal and Transport (PTP): a. Develops and evaluates policies, systems, procedures and mail and transportation services b. Serves as Contracting Officer Representatives (CORs) on Mail and Transportation contacts and Tenders of Service (

) Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS)/Office of the Director Facilities Support/Logistics: a. Oversees the operation of the Mail Management program. b. Establishes a Territory Point of Contact (TPOC) who provides mail agement program guidance for mailroom operations and mail within their Territory. c. Coordinates Servicewide ﬁeld office mailroom operations and mail delivery services d. Serves as the Contracting Officer’s Representatives (COR) for the National Mailroom Services Contract, and the National Postal Contract e. Communicates changes in policy to ﬁeld offices f. Provides TPOCs with training and education (

) Business Operating Divisions (BOD) assign Local Points of Contact IRS Field offices that are not serviced by the Primary Mail Contractor. LPOC serves as the primary contact for the FMSS Mail Program TPOC. (
) PTP reconciles postal meter charges and credits from the USPS for the (
) The following forms and reports are used for control of the program: • OMAS report • Vendor Meter Reset Report • IPAC Billing Document (

-A, Postage Purchase/Expenditure Report, is used to reconcile meter charges and credits from the USPS for the IRS. (

Terms Frequently used Terms and Deﬁnitions Term Deﬁnition Electronic Shipping Label A type of identiﬁcation label that includes the origin/return address, the destination address, package weight, type of shipment (Ground, 2nd Day Air, etc) and a tracking barcode. Electronic Tracking Number and Tracking number and barcode are Shipping Barcode automatically generated by the carrier. Postage Meters Machines or systems approved by the Postal Service that print postage directly onto your mailpiece or on to meter tape, which you affix to your mail. They are available for lease only from authorized providers. Acronyms Frequently used Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition

, Postage Meters and PC Postage Products
1.22 Mail and Transportation Management

) Postage meters are available only by lease from authorized meter providers. All IRS meters must be penalty postage meters to facilitate payment through Meters the Official Mail Accounting System (OMAS). The United States Postal (USPS) holds providers responsible for the control, operation, maintenance and replacement of their meters when necessary. No one other than an rized provider may possess a postage meter without a valid rental (

) The Office of Procurement, Southern Region - Midstates Section has negoti- ated a national meter contract to provide nationwide postage meter and maintenance to IRS offices. The provider is subject to change when the current contract expires. Therefore, it is important to check with the FMSS Territory Point of Contact (TPOC) for the current provider. (

) All IRS postage meters must use the remote Computerized Meter Resetting System (CMRS), which allows a meter to be reset/reﬁlled using telephone technology. The initial dollar amount of postage set and subsequent reﬁlls paid through the OMAS, which is established with the USPS. (
) The amount of postage to be placed on the meter should be equal to the average amount of postage expended in a month. This applies to the initial and subsequent reﬁlls. (
) A list of authorized postage meter providers is contained in Chapter
of USPS Domestic Mail Manual (DMM). Meter Providers (

) Meter licensee responsibilities include: a. Securing the meter to prevent any unauthorized use and prevent Meter Customer to the meter components b. Keeping the meter in IRS custody until returned to the authorized provider
Meter licensee responsibilities include:

Securing the meter to prevent any unauthorized use and prevent to the meter components Keeping the meter in IRS custody until returned to the authorized provider Recording each day’s readings of the ascending and descending registers
If a postage meter inspection is not performed, USPS will not allow the meter

When a meter is taken out of service, all unused postage loaded on the meter is credited to the IRS OMAS account. Copies of daily ascending and descend- ing meter readings may be required as supporting documentation.
Access to the meter must be controlled. Each meter is equipped with

-number PIN to lock and unlock the meter. Refer to the meter user guide for this information. At the end of the workday, the meter must be placed in the locked position. Offices with after-hours cleaning must secure the meter in a locked interior room or in a locked cabinet each evening. Offices that do not have an intrusion detection system must secure meter in a locked interior room or a locked cabinet.
1.22.8.3 (01-21-2021) Small Package Carrier (SPC) Technology Options

Carrier provided shipping system - This is a standalone computer system that is provided to large office locations. These systems are typically provided to Campus/Submission Processing locations and IRS locations with a contractor staffed mailroom. A Form
, Request for Mail/ Shipping Service, is required to generate the shipping label
1.22 Mail and Transportation Management

b. Carrier web site - This is primarily used in smaller locations that do not have contract mailrooms. It is an internet-based program from which users can easily generate an electronic shipping label, using their computer, printer and plain printer paper. Users are registered and access to the program by a Postal and Transport Policy Section employee Note: Employees that ship packages after the mailroom closes should request access to the Carrier web site, so they can generate electronic shipping labels. Manually prepared labels should only be used as a last resort (
) All electronic equipment and web sites are subject to failures and Rebooting a system and/or stepping away for
to

minutes may resolve Carrier situation. If not, follow one of the options below: a. Carrier provided shipping systems - Contact the TPOC/LPOC and Failure them of the breakdown. If known, call the local carrier representative advise them of the situation. Replacement software/hardware and technical support must be provided by the equipment owner b. Carrier web site - Attempt to open the internet site. If this web site will load, the problem is internal and not external. Most web site failures due to an IRS network problem and not related to the SPC web site (
) If unable to resolve, manually prepare
nd Day Air and/or Next Day Air shipping documents to ensure timely delivery of high priority shipments. Manually prepared labels should only be used as a last resort.
a. Carrier provided shipping systems

Contact the TPOC/LPOC and advise them of the breakdown. If known, call the local carrier representative and advise them of the situation. Replacement software/hardware and technical support must be provided by the equipment owner b. Carrier web site

Attempt to open the internet site. If this web site will not load, the problem is internal and not external. Most web site failures are due to an IRS network problem and not related to the SPC web site

If unable to resolve, manually prepare 2nd Day Air and/or Next Day Air shipping documents to ensure timely delivery of high priority shipments. Manually prepared labels should only be used as a last resort.
